channel.title: Favorite/Best way to store data in Java
channel.description:
I used to use ArrayLists a lot, but they give me so much problems. What are your opinions on the best way to store data.
Your opinions might vary based on what you're trying to store, but if you'd like, leave your favorite and say why you like it, and use it.

item.title: Favorite/Best way to store data in Java
item.dc:creator: @asshole_rule asshole_rule
item.description:
@asshole_rule wrote:

[quote=“t4, post:37, topic:440268”][quote author=asshole_rule link=topic=542942.msg3983252#msg3983252 date=1335553871]

most of moparscape has no fucking clue what it is

exactly my fucking point, i figured i would learn a bit from making this topic. Although you’re attempting to teach the community, you’re way to quick to jump on peoples mistakes/stupidity.
[/quote]
if you wanted to learn the uses for common data collection structures, you could have simply asked that; furthermore i am ‘quick to jump on people’s mistakes/stupidity’ because the topic of these data structures is intro-level, not to mention i posted very early on in the topic why this is a stupid question, yet no one listened. i figured a very verbose, ‘in your face’ approach would be the best solution.

did you at least learn something?[/quote]

yep.

Read full topic

item.source: Favorite/Best way to store data in Java

item.title: Favorite/Best way to store data in Java
item.dc:creator: @Advocatus Advocatus
item.description:
@Advocatus wrote:

[quote=“t4, post:33, topic:440268”][quote author=sinisoul link=topic=542942.msg3982894#msg3982894 date=1335494636]

itt people that don’t understand data structure specialisation

exactly, this topic is fucking retarded.

^^^^

protip: Using a map would be better than using an array in this situation.
[/quote]
wat is a map i just use two array lists lol ? /1[/quote]
Haha, one for the keys and one for the values <3.

On the topic of data storage, i view it as a personal preference. You basically categorize them in so many different ways that I find doing so to be insane. Two of these categories would be serialized vs. non serialized (TSV, CSV, binary, etc).

On the topic of serialization I either use googles protocol buffers, or I just say fuck it and use object outputstream. The limits of using objectoutputstream (limited to java, fugly, high overhead) are not large enough to persuade me to use protocol buffers all the time.

However, I think you were more referring to preferred collection.
On this topic, I side with sini.
I will either use a basic Stack implementation (if there is no problem with it being FILO), a map (since it has O(1) lookup time it is very nice for data storage), or just arrays. Lately I have been using HashMaps even less. I used to use them all the time; however, when I was going through my code a few months ago I noticed that I was using them in cases when the fast lookup time is not that beneficial compared to what is spent in allocating it.

Read full topic
item.source: Favorite/Best way to store data in Java

item.source: Favorite/Best way to store data in Java

item.title: Favorite/Best way to store data in Java
item.dc:creator: @Wet_Dreamss Wet Dreamss
item.description:
@Wet_Dreamss wrote:

[quote=“t4, post:28, topic:440268”][quote author=Wet Dreamss link=topic=542942.msg3982829#msg3982829 date=1335489310]

itt people that don’t understand data structure specialisation

exactly, this topic is fucking retarded.

Asking peoples opinions is retarded?

You’ve got your head too far up your ass.

if you have an opinion/preference on a type of data structure for holding collections of data then you clearly don’t know anything about common collection data structures. the structure one should use for a specific collection should solely be based on how one wishes to access the structure and hardware constraints.

want to know why? because there’s this thing called time complexity! not only does time complexity matter, but so does memory usage!
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dynamic_array#Performance
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hash_table (see time complexity portion)

and judging by most of the replies to this thread, most of moparscape has no fucking clue what it is; so i advise you all to look at this:
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Time_complexity
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Big_O_notation

I’ll stay uninformed on most things that have to do with java, and continue to act like I know a shit ton when the reality is I know very little, and I’ll just continue my daily trolling.
[/quote]
i’m confused, but those structures aren’t unique to java…[/quote]
I know, but this is mainly a Java site, Storing isn’t unique to java at all, I’d just stay uninformed still :3

Read full topic
item.source: Favorite/Best way to store data in Java

item.title: Favorite/Best way to store data in Java
item.dc:creator: @T41 t4
item.description:
@T41 wrote:

[quote=“Wet Dreamss, post:27, topic:440268”][quote author=t4 link=topic=542942.msg3982751#msg3982751 date=1335484264]

itt people that don’t understand data structure specialisation

exactly, this topic is fucking retarded.

Asking peoples opinions is retarded?

You’ve got your head too far up your ass.

if you have an opinion/preference on a type of data structure for holding collections of data then you clearly don’t know anything about common collection data structures. the structure one should use for a specific collection should solely be based on how one wishes to access the structure and hardware constraints.

want to know why? because there’s this thing called time complexity! not only does time complexity matter, but so does memory usage!

en.wikipedia.org

Dynamic array

In computer science, a dynamic array, growable array, resizable array, dynamic table, mutable array, or array list is a random access, variable-size list data structure that allows elements to be added or removed. It is supplied with standard libraries in many modern mainstream programming languages. Dynamic arrays overcome a limit of static arrays, which have a fixed capacity that needs to be specified at allocation. A dynamic array is not the same thing as a dynamically allocated array, which i...


http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hash_table (see time complexity portion)

and judging by most of the replies to this thread, most of moparscape has no fucking clue what it is; so i advise you all to look at this:

en.wikipedia.org

Time complexity

In computer science, the time complexity is the computational complexity that measures or estimates the time taken for running an algorithm. Time complexity is commonly estimated by counting the number of elementary operations performed by the algorithm, supposing that an elementary operation takes a fixed amount of time to perform. Thus, the amount of time taken and the number of elementary operations performed by the algorithm differ by at most a constant factor. Since an algorithm's running ti...


en.wikipedia.org

Big O notation

Big O notation is a mathematical notation that describes the limiting behaviour of a function when the argument tends towards a particular value or infinity. It is a member of a family of notations invented by Paul Bachmann, Edmund Landau, and others, collectively called Bachmann–Landau notation or asymptotic notation. In computer science, big O notation is used to classify algorithms according to how their running time or space requirements grow as the input size grows. In analytic number theory...


[/quote]
I’ll stay uninformed on most things that have to do with java, and continue to act like I know a shit ton when the reality is I know very little, and I’ll just continue my daily trolling.[/quote]
i’m confused, but those structures aren’t unique to java…

Read full topic
